body.header: What will I learn in this unit?
body.section:
Conversation (social context)You will listen to a telephone conversation where someone books tickets for a theatre production.
Monologue (educational context)You will listen to a lecture on the history of British cinemas.
Question typesYou will attempt two question types.Form completionClassification

section.p: You are usually given a form that needs to be filled in with personal details or other factual information using information from the listening text.
Read the instructions carefully. They will usually state that your answer should be NO MORE THAN THREE WORDS OR A NUMBER. But check this is the case.
Read through the form and decide what you need to listen for. Forms will often require details like names and addresses. Take note of any headings.
You may be able to predict one or two of the answers.
Complete the form as you listen. The information will be given in the same order as the spaces in the form.
Use the words you hear, not your own.
Remember as you write, the answer could be a number, one word, two words or three words but not four words or more.
If you think you need more than three words your answer is probably incorrect.

These questions ask you to classify information given in the listening text. Classifications are often according to the speaker's opinion or according to a period of time. You will be asked to write a letter representing one of the classifications beside each item in a list of statements.
Read the instructions carefully. Make sure you know how many classifications there are and what letters you have to use.
Read the classifications carefully and make sure you know which letter represents which one.
Read the statements and make yourself as familiar with them as possible. You will hear them all mentioned but they may be expressed differently in the text.
Underline the key words in both the classifications and the statements.
The information will be given in the same order as the numbered statements.
Listen out for the words you have underlined.
Don't leave any statements without a letter.
